Cosgrove, John H.
Interview conducted by Jochen Kraske and William Becker, on 1995-05-03
Cosgrove covers his educational and professional background prior to coming to the Bank in 1991 as Executive Director (ED) representing the Western Pacific constituency numbering 12 countries. Starting at the Australian Treasury in the early 60's, he worked mostly on domestic economic analysis and policy issues which subsequently took him to the Australian Mission to the European Community in Brussels in 1973, the OECD in Paris in 1974, back in Canberra in 1976 working on international issues, a second posting overseas to the High Commission in London (1982-1985), then back to the Treasury in Canberra until he was appointed ED at the Bank.
Cosgrove discusses briefly the structure of the Australian Government, its membership in the multilateral financial institutions, and the Treasury's philosophical perspective and Australia's evolving philosophical position on economic matters. According to Cosgrove, in spite of the Treasury's orthodoxy it has undertaken quite a few important reforms over the years, especially, in the area of microeconomics which saw the removal of quite a few structural barriers to economic growth and freeing up the market to the rest of the world.
Cosgrove discusses his objectives and accomplishments as ED, his chair's firm approach on the Bank's budget in general, and balancing the various interests of the constituencies he represents. He stresses the distinction between finance and development assistance, and maintains that the Bank is more focused on financial transfers and not sufficiently focused on economic development. In line with the Australian Treasury's underlying economic philosophy, he strongly feels that self-help goes a long way; a principle that applies to almost any country. To that effect, he talks of the Bank and Fund's crucial role in bringing about a sound economic framework with emphasis on capacity building, and points to the lack of effective technical assistance.
In light of the general tendency of Board members to act as Ambassadors, he stresses the specific role of an ED as a member of the Bank's Executive Board as well as an official of the Bank. In that context, he talks of his rapport with the shareholders and Canberra specifically. He discusses Australia's weightier role as a bigger stakeholder in the Asian Development Bank than in the Bank, at the same time, cites the reasons for Australia's declining financial input in both institutions and specifically in its IDA contributions, and Australia's two major export markets in Asia, Japan and Korea, and the Association of the Asia-Pacific Economic Corporation (APEC).
Cosgrove addresses the workings of the Board, his relationship with its members, and the impediment of frequent turnovers. The review of Board procedures, and his support of the recommendations of the Haralz-Naim report. He elaborates on the ensuing reforms resulting in, among other things, improved Board/Management relations but with still rather limited informal contact, the Board's increased influence in covering policy issues even though he still feels that the Board is weak and should be more determined about its role as the decision- making body of this organization. He opines on certain remedial steps that he would like to see put into effect, offers a rationale of the underlying tension between Management and the Board and, in that context, assesses the roles of Presidents Conable and Preston.
On Board representation, he talks of the advantages in having a smaller Board and mentions the postponement of reviewing the Board's structure and composition. Again, he discusses the need for effective technical assistance, argues against the Bank's involvement in areas that lie outside of its comparative advantage, such as granting money to U.N. agencies to help them finance their own operations, and getting involved in micro-credit type facilities. He praises the Bank's achievements on environmental issues, and the pivotal role of the U.S. chair in easing pressures from environmentalists associated with the execution of some Bank projects.
Cosgrove discusses the reasons why he does not favor an inspection panel, the Bank's progress on the issue of women in development, opines on the notion of the Bank as a 'bloated bureaucracy' including its over generous remuneration, Management's handling of staff reductions, his disappointment in seeing less coming in the way of savings from higher productivity per employee-on which he elaborates--than from lowering the number of employees, and concludes in stressing the crucial role of the shareholders in affecting change in terms of cost consciousness and accountability in the Bank.

doc.abstracts: In May 1995, John H. Cosgrove was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Jochen Kraske and William Becker. During his World Bank tenure from 1991 to 1995, Mr. Cosgrove served as executive director representing the Western Pacific states. Cosgrove discusses his objectives and accomplishments as executive director. His transcript concerns his relationship with the board and its members, the progress of the World Bank on the issue of women in development, and its handling of staff reductions. He concludes his discussion by stressing the crucial role of shareholders in affecting change in terms of cost consciousness and accountability in the World Bank.
